dataset.title: Report: SANParks Gobal Envionmental Change Project: Habitat Change Summary Report

abstract.para:
Change creates uncertainty and risk. Global environmental change epitomizes several threats and risks to human livelihoods. Numerous factors associate with and drive global environmental change including climate, disease, pollution, invasive species, over-harvesting and habitat change. In many instances, protected areas are considered the holy grail of ensuring environmental sustainability, even though continental patterns challenge this. Such areas are usually embedded in matrices of different land-uses, all of which may have different consequences for the environment. In South Africa, it is not clear how protected areas combat or are affected by global patterns of environmental change.
The definition of habitat change is problematic on two fronts. Firstly, habitat change can be viewed as primarily a consequence and/or indicator of the effects of other drivers of global environmental change. Secondly, desirable and undesirable habitat changes need to be separated. A range of causes of habitat change (sub-drivers) were identified across parks at a meeting of SANParks research staff at the Cape Research Centre. These include fire, absence of predators, over-grazing, mega-herbivore impact, park isolation, small park size, water abstraction, management for tourism, sedimentation, poaching and overexploitation. Two positive impacts on habitat were identified, i.e. land consolidation and restoration. One of the key conclusions from the discussion was that there is good evidence for the fact that habitat in parks is changing, but that the impact of this change on pattern and process in parks is poorly understood. Objectives were set in this context and the assessment focused on two kinds of data sets – vegetation measures (species composition) across parks as a primary index of habitat change, and large mammal abundances within parks as a broad index of a response to habitat change.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: South African National Parks, South Africa

section.para: 672 papers and their abstracts were extracted from the Science Citation Database using the “habitat change” and “protected area” as search words. Only the papers published since 1 January 2008 were considered. Results suggest that habitat change associated with land use change and fragmentation, processes that are limited within Parks at the scale usually used in other studies.

Vegetation plot data were collated from the South African National Parks into one central database. A total of 33 data sets have been collected and converted into a standard ‘species by site’ format or a ‘presence/absence’ format. Several data sets may still be added to the total number as some researchers that were contacted need to sort their data and/or finish field plots before they can provide it. A number of hard copy data sets was also included. The 33 data sets currently collated represent 15 of the national parks.

All large mammal time series data available from surveys for National Parks were collated. We reasoned that the responses of large mammals summarized by growth rates that reflect biological influences of resources, members of its own species as well as other species, will serve as good indicators of the impact of habitat change even if indicators of habitat change are limited. We thus calculated exponential growth rates in the past five years.

funding.para: SANParks PDF; Andrew W. Mellon Foundation
